Unriggable

So they (pro-life peeps) say abortion is murder. Of course, you can only murder people. So their rule is that fetuses (feti?) are people also. But then they can't explain why fetuses aren't listed on the US Census, or why there isn't a funeral every time a woman has a miscarriage. Pretty much, along with the rules of having children, you would have to acquire the birth certificate during conception, you would have to pay taxes for children, even if you're only pregnant, etc.
 
 Or am I missing something? Care to clarify, anybody who disagrees?

post_info.post_title: Time to settle this once and for all

Archangel

So they (pro-life peeps) say abortion is murder. Of course, you can only murder people. So their rule is that fetuses (feti?) are people also. But then they can't explain why fetuses aren't listed on the US Census, or why there isn't a funeral every time a woman has a miscarriage. Pretty much, along with the rules of having children, you would have to acquire the birth certificate during conception, you would have to pay taxes for children, even if you're only pregnant, etc.
 
 Or am I missing something? Care to clarify, anybody who disagrees?

 
 And how do you propose to settle this once and for all unless you admit that in order for the egg and the sperm to come together and form a child in 9 months that original life existed within each of them. Not only that, but the resulting offspring is a combination of the features and characteristics of the two parents who copulated. To imply that an unborn child is not human/a person simply because it isn't fully developed is to also claim that a person born without limbs must not be human either because they too are incomplete human beings. 
 
 
Of course, you can only murder people. So their rule is that fetuses (feti?) are people also.

 
 Then explain to me why a pregnant woman was hit by a car not long ago leading to the death of both mother and baby. Resulting in a double vehicular homicide charge being leveled against the driver ? How can that be if the unborn child doesn't have rights as a human being ? And why could the mother have aborted that baby legally if she chose to ? Isn't that a true catch 22 for the unborn, and a contradiction in the law ? 
 
 And the answer to the rest of your fallacious argument is that it isn't so much that the unborn are people but are persons with unalienable rights to develop into a sentient beings. To deny them of that is the murder of every bit of potential that exists within them just as when a 5 year old child is hit by a car, it is a waste of all of his future potential. After all, a 2 day old baby is no more valuable or independent potentially speaking than an unborn child is 2 days before it's born, but the 2 day old child has all of the rights that you have to life. Weird huh ? That doesn't make any sense at all does it ? By your standard of reasoning, no person should be considered sentient and deserving of human and civil rights until they can prove some inherent value to the State. Such as an age when they can work and produce a product or service that is valuable to someone other than themselves.
 
 And why would a birth certificate be necessary at conception ? The statement in and of itself is ridiculous. We conceive a child in the hope of accomplishing a complete gestation period, but just as we don't register a car before we purchase it, neither would we apply for a birth certificate before the child is born. But not being born does not mean it doesn't yet exist as is proven by the growth and pre-natal care exercised by the mother in anticipation of a healthy child.
Phyllis

But then they can't explain why fetuses aren't listed on the US Census...

 
 I'm not sure what this proves. Residents of Indonesia are not listed on the US Census either. Does this make Indonesians non persons?
 
 
or why there isn't a funeral every time a woman has a miscarriage.

 
 There were not funerals every time a Jew was slaughtered at a concentration camp during WWII. Does this mean that the Jews were non persons?
 
 
Pretty much, along with the rules of having children, you would have to acquire the birth certificate during conception...

 
 Does this mean that if one has the unfortunate luck of having lost their state issued birth certificate then they are no longer a person?
 
 
You would have to pay taxes for children, even if you're only pregnant, etc.

 
 I'm not sure where this one even comes from. But regardless, does this mean that if the tax code didn't exist then people likewise would not exist?
 
 I don't think much has been settled in this thread.
 
 
Or am I missing something? Care to clarify, anybody who disagrees?

 
 As Archangel pointed out, you are missing the numerous states that prosecute for double homicide if one murders a pregnant woman.
Zardoz

So they (pro-life peeps) say abortion is murder. Of course, you can only murder people. So their rule is that fetuses (feti?) are people also. But then they can't explain why fetuses aren't listed on the US Census, or why there isn't a funeral every time a woman has a miscarriage. Pretty much, along with the rules of having children, you would have to acquire the birth certificate during conception, you would have to pay taxes for children, even if you're only pregnant, etc.
 
 Or am I missing something? Care to clarify, anybody who disagrees?

 
 Murder is a subjective and legal term.
 It doesn't always apply to 'people'. Nor even 'Humans'.
 It can include the Fetus in some cases.
 
 As ws said, being listed on the Census doesn't mean much.
 I've worked for the US Census Bureau in the past. I listed all sorts of things that weren't proper by most people definitions.
 I even had Jesus H. Christ as a Portugese roommate. So what?
 
 Humans can be born without certificates and even exist off the 'grid' in many cases. I wonder if the Amish qualify as persons.
 
 Furthermore, you'd not pay taxes (in many parts of a pregnancy, taxes are paid on it's care though) but, you'd get a tax break for the 'kid (or whatever it is)'.
 Want that?
simone

So they (pro-life peeps) say abortion is murder. Of course, you can only murder people. So their rule is that fetuses (feti?) are people also. But then they can't explain why fetuses aren't listed on the US Census, or why there isn't a funeral every time a woman has a miscarriage. Pretty much, along with the rules of having children, you would have to acquire the birth certificate during conception, you would have to pay taxes for children, even if you're only pregnant, etc.
 
 Or am I missing something? Care to clarify, anybody who disagrees?

 Unriggable, your statement should read the so-called "pro-life" since they are anything but.
Aivlis

I have to admit that I agree with Arch for the most part on this one. There are people in the world that believe a fetus is a human being but also believe in a womans right to choose, I am one of them. I can't be in denial so much as to convince myself that a fetus is not a real human being, of course it is. However, knowing that does not mean that I am against abortion. I think that most sensible people would agree with this perspective. Anybody who says that a fetus is not a person needs to get their head out of their XXX.
jitobear
This is never going to get settled in everyone's mind "once and for all" - people aren't like that.
thelmoose

I agree that this does not settle anything, it merely points out that the unborn do not have all of the same legal recognitions that the born have. I for one, am dead set against allowing the unborn to vote... and drive. 
 
 Seriously, I do not think that anyone can say that an unborn human, from zygote to delivery is not alive. Nor can it be said it is not a homo sapiens or human. It is an unborn but living human. 
 
 Whether it is a person simply depends upon what you define as personhood. What rights one wishes to confer on that unborn that are independent of the mother who is carrying it is what this argument is all about. 
 
 To say the unborn is exactly the same as the born is simply not an arguable point to me. One is born and the other is not. That is not a trivial difference. One's existence is inextricable related to another person in a way that is strikingly different from any relationship a born human has. 
 
 I just wish we could address this issue as whether or not abortion should be legal or not. The two sides should be called "pro legalized abortion" and "anti legalized abortion" and talk about the pros and cons of this legalization rather than reducing this to metaphysical arguments that can never be decided. Although this is understandably an emotionally laden topic for all sides, reducing the argument to emotion does not solve anything and looking at things from a more pragmatic point of view is what is needed. 
 
 Some people think abortion is wrong and should not be legal. Those people need to realistically think about the consequences of making abortions illegal and work more toward reducing unwanted preganancies. It makes the debate of abortions moot if there are no unwanted pregancies.
 
 Some people think abortion is not wrong and should be legal. Those people need to realistically think about the consequences of having abortions legal and work more toward reducing unwanted preganancies. It makes the debate of abortions moot if there are no unwanted pregancies.
Zardoz

I agree that this does not settle anything, it merely points out that the unborn do not have all of the same legal recognitions that the born have. I for one, am dead set against allowing the unborn to vote... and drive.

 But...but...
 I just swallowed 56 zygotes so that they could vote by proxy through me for the Ripofflican(tm) party this upcoming election so they can win. Now I'm going to have all that indigestion for nothin'.
 As to driving...don't care. 
 What I'll miss most is all of those credit card offers that come in their names. There's just so much that they, living though me want to 'buy now and pay later' on. You saying they can't do that? 
 
 
Seriously, I do not think that anyone can say that an unborn human, from zygote to delivery is not alive. Nor can it be said it is not a homo sapiens or human. It is an unborn but living human.

 But, that's just the argument Chem99a and I are having in another thread.
 
 
Whether it is a person simply depends upon what you define as personhood. What rights one wishes to confer on that unborn that are independent of the mother who is carrying it is what this argument is all about.

 And this is what it devolves down into. 
 
 
To say the unborn is exactly the same as the born is simply not an arguable point to me. One is born and the other is not. That is not a trivial difference. One's existence is inextricable related to another person in a way that is strikingly different from any relationship a born human has.

 Parasite attached to a human and one that's coaxes it (often with governmental support) to nurish it...not much difference.
 Personally, I'd rather have the sucker permanently attached to me so I'm not forced to think about feeding it or changing it's diaper. I'd also take a kick to the ribs over cholic crying.
 Silly neglegence laws...
 
 
I just wish we could address this issue as whether or not abortion should be legal or not. The two sides should be called "pro legalized abortion" and "anti legalized abortion" and talk about the pros and cons of this legalization rather than reducing this to metaphysical arguments that can never be decided. Although this is understandably an emotionally laden topic for all sides, reducing the argument to emotion does not solve anything and looking at things from a more pragmatic point of view is what is needed.

 Yep.
 I do think some would be willing to work towards compromises that would make the most happy. Jitobear seems to be one from my observations.
 But, others want it their way. 
 I dislike abortion but can see in some circumstances that there really isn't much of an alternative. I also see that most anti-abortionists often don't help to provide alternatives.
 
 I don't want to make it illegal per se but do want to work towards reducing the instrances in which a woman would see it as a more viable alternative. 
 
 It'd be nice if society and science would progress to that point.
 But, since it isn't and since I'm evil(tm), kill it.
 Go ahead...be a murderer.
 Muahahahaha.
 Evil WINS!
 Go evil, go evil, go evil...
 
 Um, isn't evil subjective?
 emoticon_confused
thelmoose

Muahahahaha.
 Evil WINS!
 Go evil, go evil, go evil...
 
 Um, isn't evil subjective?
 

 
 I would think in some cases, evil is subjective.
 In your case, I think you are definitely objectively evil. I like that in a person.
 
 By the way, your signature about "A Norse kid born with his heart on the outside (wrapped in barbed wire) " explains a lot. That what all those blond, blue-eyed statues are all about. 
 Funny stuff, thanks.
Sigma

To say the unborn is exactly the same as the born is simply not an arguable point to me. One is born and the other is not. That is not a trivial difference. One's existence is inextricable related to another person in a way that is strikingly different from any relationship a born human has. 
 
 I just wish we could address this issue as whether or not abortion should be legal or not. The two sides should be called "pro legalized abortion" and "anti legalized abortion" and talk about the pros and cons of this legalization rather than reducing this to metaphysical arguments that can never be decided. Although this is understandably an emotionally laden topic for all sides, reducing the argument to emotion does not solve anything and looking at things from a more pragmatic point of view is what is needed.

 
 The arguments are entwined. 
 
 Those who believe there is a moral equivalence would believe there is or should be a legal equivalence between the conceptus and a born child and can not abide allowing either to be killed.
 
 Showing a rational moral difference allows for the inclusion of a rational legal difference. While, currently, the legal difference does have support under the Constitution those who blindly and irrationally believe there is a moral equivalence will attempt to change that which results in this endless war between the two sides.
chemist99a

I agree that this does not settle anything, it merely points out that the unborn do not have all of the same legal recognitions that the born have. I for one, am dead set against allowing the unborn to vote... and drive.

 
 Or to own guns emoticon_xkill
Zardoz

I would think in some cases, evil is subjective.
 In your case, I think you are definitely objectively evil. I like that in a person.
 
 By the way, your signature about "A Norse kid born with his heart on the outside (wrapped in barbed wire) " explains a lot. That what all those blond, blue-eyed statues are all about. 
 Funny stuff, thanks.

 
 
 Some of my greatest stuff is stolen from other sources and altered to fit the subject.
 The Norse kid comment is a rip off from the movie Raising Arizona.
 "Say that reminds me, how'd you get that kid so darn fast? Me and Dot went in to adopt on account a' somethin' went wrong with my semen, and they said we had to wait five years for a healthy white baby. I said, "Healthy white baby? Five years? What else you got?" Said they got two Koreans and a negra born with his heart on the outside. It's a crazy world."
thelmoose

The arguments are entwined. 
 
 Those who believe there is a moral equivalence would believe there is or should be a legal equivalence between the conceptus and a born child and can not abide allowing either to be killed.
 
 Showing a rational moral difference allows for the inclusion of a rational legal difference. While, currently, the legal difference does have support under the Constitution those who blindly and irrationally believe there is a moral equivalence will attempt to change that which results in this endless war between the two sides.

 
 I agree.
 The arguments are entwined to the degree we choose to entwine them, though. While morality and ethics certainly ought to play a part in how we write our laws, they are different concepts. Clearly not everything that is legal is moral and not all immoral acts are illegal. 
 
 If anything is clear in this whole debate is that the two sides of the moral debate have irreconcilable differences and will never, ever agree on this. So perhaps we should approach by stopping an argument about that which can never be resolved.
Shooterandproud

So they (pro-life peeps) say abortion is murder. Of course, you can only murder people. So their rule is that fetuses (feti?) are people also. But then they can't explain why fetuses aren't listed on the US Census, or why there isn't a funeral every time a woman has a miscarriage. Pretty much, along with the rules of having children, you would have to acquire the birth certificate during conception, you would have to pay taxes for children, even if you're only pregnant, etc.
 
 Or am I missing something? Care to clarify, anybody who disagrees?

 
 Yes, you are missing something. How come age doesn't start at conception? How come when babies are born they aren't 9 months old instead of, well, seconds old.
Shooterandproud

And how do you propose to settle this once and for all unless you admit that in order for the egg and the sperm to come together and form a child in 9 months that original life existed within each of them. Not only that, but the resulting offspring is a combination of the features and characteristics of the two parents who copulated. To imply that an unborn child is not human/a person simply because it isn't fully developed is to also claim that a person born without limbs must not be human either because they too are incomplete human beings.

 
 It is not because they are incomplete, it is because they have no mental existence or personhood. If you decapitate a person, and the body was kept alive, is that still a person? If you cut off a person's arm and keep the body alive, is that still a person? Obviously no for scenario 1 and yes for scenario 2.
 
 
 
 
Then explain to me why a pregnant woman was hit by a car not long ago leading to the death of both mother and baby. Resulting in a double vehicular homicide charge being leveled against the driver ? How can that be if the unborn child doesn't have rights as a human being ? And why could the mother have aborted that baby legally if she chose to ? Isn't that a true catch 22 for the unborn, and a contradiction in the law ?

 
 I dunno, maybe it was in the third trimester?
 
 
 
And the answer to the rest of your fallacious argument is that it isn't so much that the unborn are people but are persons with unalienable rights to develop into a sentient beings. To deny them of that is the murder of every bit of potential that exists within them just as when a 5 year old child is hit by a car, it is a waste of all of his future potential.

 
 I'm sure that every sperm deserves to develop into a sentient being too, right? So then ejaculation is murder too.
 
 
 
 
After all, a 2 day old baby is no more valuable or independent potentially speaking than an unborn child is 2 days before it's born, but the 2 day old child has all of the rights that you have to life.

 
 So does the 2 day before birth unborn child because it is in the third trimester. I as in what you have come to know as ME was born somewhere in the third trimester. The body that I'm sitting in this chair with and typing this with was born at conception, and started as a sperm before conception.
 
 
 
 
Weird huh ? That doesn't make any sense at all does it ? By your standard of reasoning, no person should be considered sentient and deserving of human and civil rights until they can prove some inherent value to the State. Such as an age when they can work and produce a product or service that is valuable to someone other than themselves.

 
 Completely irrelevant as human beings have brains and are sentient.
 
 
 
And why would a birth certificate be necessary at conception ? The statement in and of itself is ridiculous. We conceive a child in the hope of accomplishing a complete gestation period, but just as we don't register a car before we purchase it, neither would we apply for a birth certificate before the child is born. But not being born does not mean it doesn't yet exist as is proven by the growth and pre-natal care exercised by the mother in anticipation of a healthy child.

 
 Exactly my point. You can't drive around without a car. Just planning to get a car will not drive you anywhere. An orange seed will not feed you but an orange tree will.
chemist99a

Then explain to me why a pregnant woman was hit by a car not long ago leading to the death of both mother and baby. Resulting in a double vehicular homicide charge being leveled against the driver ? How can that be if the unborn child doesn't have rights as a human being ? And why could the mother have aborted that baby legally if she chose to ? Isn't that a true catch 22 for the unborn, and a contradiction in the law ?

 
 Because that the law one has to presume and of course the law applied to that specific case. As to it being contradictory - well the law is loaded with contradictions if you look at all closely. On the other hand consider that the driver killed the woman AND obviously damaged her fetus beyond recovery - WITHOUT the consent of the woman. In other words the death of the fetus was not by consent of the person who holds the right to decide but rather by the negligence or intent of the guilty party.
 
 And yes prior to her death (assumming all other requirements were met) she could have AT HER CHOICE and UN-COERCED have chosen to abort the fetus without incurring a legal penalty. But that would of course be much different.
chemist99a

And why would a birth certificate be necessary at conception ? The statement in and of itself is ridiculous. We conceive a child in the hope of accomplishing a complete gestation period, but just as we don't register a car before we purchase it, neither would we apply for a birth certificate before the child is born. But not being born does not mean it doesn't yet exist as is proven by the growth and pre-natal care exercised by the mother in anticipation of a healthy child.

 
 I can only add to the previous post that the mother may NOT have exercised all that pre-natal effort etc if she intends to have an abortion as is her right and privilevge.
 
 Pregnant women have for example been arrested for consuming too much alcohol and thus endangering the fetus. The obvious defense is of course that she intended to have an abortion the next day and was celebrating her decision before the event.
Axolotl

To deny them [the unborn] of that is the murder of every bit of potential that exists within them just as when a 5 year old child is hit by a car, it is a waste of all of his future potential. 

 
 We cannot take something away from someone who does not yet exist.
 
 

 After all, a 2 day old baby is no more valuable or independent potentially speaking than an unborn child is 2 days before it's born, but the 2 day old child has all of the rights that you have to life. 

 
 We cannot abort a fetus that is viable outside the womb. Abortion is a process that, in and of itself, destroys the life of the fetus or embryo regardless of whatever procedures are taken concerning that life before the fetus or embryo is removed from the womb.
 
 Therefore, there is no question around abortion under such circumstances, to begin with. Nothing to debate.
 
 At that point, we are talking about childbirth.
Axolotl

And why would a birth certificate be necessary at conception ? The statement in and of itself is ridiculous. We conceive a child in the hope of accomplishing a complete gestation period, but just as we don't register a car before we purchase it, neither would we apply for a birth certificate before the child is born. But not being born does not mean it doesn't yet exist as is proven by the growth and pre-natal care exercised by the mother in anticipation of a healthy child.

 
 Papers on individual cars are issued by the manufacturers when the car is completed, and before purchase. IMO, that is the more accurate analogy to the certificate denoting a human being's full development (at the factory), ability to birth, and having done so. 
 
 Then parent/s get a social security number (registration) and drive it off the lot or head home from the hospital. (Roughly speaking, though children are allowed to register later without penalty)
chemist99a

Originally Posted by Archangel 
 After all, a 2 day old baby is no more valuable or independent potentially speaking than an unborn child is 2 days before it's born, but the 2 day old child has all of the rights that you have to life. 

 
 You forget the labor theory of value. A child in the womb has had less labor applied to it than one which has been born. Two days after birth even more resources - biological and social - have been invested in it. And yes a 2 day old child is legally a person. But a 2 day old zygote is not.

in order for the egg and the sperm to come together and form a child in 9 months that original life existed within each of them. Not only that, but the resulting offspring is a combination of the features and characteristics of the two parents who copulated.

 Nothing that you said there has anything to do with the legal definition of the word 'murder'. Have fun cleaning the pan cooking your red herring ;) 
 
 
To imply that an unborn child is not human/a person 

 Just because it is human doesn't mean it's a human being. I'm not sure what grade you're in but that's basic biology 101. Your ears are human. Your ears are NOT human beings. emoticon_idea
Colonel Ingus
gman

So they (pro-life peeps) say abortion is murder. Of course, you can only murder people. So their rule is that fetuses (feti?) are people also. But then they can't explain why fetuses aren't listed on the US Census, or why there isn't a funeral every time a woman has a miscarriage. Pretty much, along with the rules of having children, you would have to acquire the birth certificate during conception, you would have to pay taxes for children, even if you're only pregnant, etc.
 
 Or am I missing something? Care to clarify, anybody who disagrees?

 
 Thinking, logical people do not automatically accept that government entities are qualified to make logical, well thought out rulings on things that truly matter. Who would ever have dreamed that officials could or ever would decide that destroying a life which exist, though it is incapable of expressing it's will to survive, as is natural for any living being, should be snuffed out at the whim of someone who indulged in the activity which produces life when they were not ready to deal with that life? Thus they give little thought to what those who spin un-thought out ideas as evidence.
